subject: RE: [junit] Junit manipulating exceptions?
msgSnippet: Frank, Are you sure that it isn t getting into the catch block?  Also, I didn t know that e.toString() returned the same thing as e.getMessage().  Is that so?
messageBody:
Frank,

Are you sure that it isn't getting into the catch block? Also, I didn't
know that e.toString() returned the same thing as e.getMessage(). Is that
so?

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Frank Enos [mailto:fenos@...]
> Sent: Friday, July 20, 2001 3:13 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Junit manipulating exceptions?
>
>
> I've provided coded examples below. My basic question is
> this: Does Junit
> (3.7) manipulate exceptions in some way that would
> prevent an exception
> from being caught in a normal try/catch block? The
> behavior I'm seeing is
> that if I attempt to catch the specific exception thrown
> by a method (e.g.
> catch (java.sql.SQLException e), the catch block fails to
> catch it and
> Junit logs it as an error. If I use catch (Exception e),
> the exception is
> caught as I would expect. I find that I can call
> getClass() on the caught
> Exception and that it returns the expected SQLException,
> whereas using
> instanceof fails.
>
> Examples (behaves the same using other methods throwing
> other exception types)
> methods are from:
> public class PersistenceTest extends TestCase {...}
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
> try {
> PersistenceManager.singleton().write("insert into
> noSuchTable
> values('junk')");
> System.out.println("No exception writing to
> non-existent table");
> } catch (SQLException e) {
> System.out.println(e.getClass().toString());
> }
> }
>
> If I simply invoke this main() method which I have added
> to the test
> class, it behaves as expected, printing the expected name
> of the class and
> exiting normally.
>
> public void testBadWrite() {
> try {
>
> PersistenceManager.singleton().write("insert into noSuchTable
> values('hey')");
> fail("No exception writing to non-existent table");
> } catch (SQLException e) {
> assertTrue(e.toString().indexOf("ORA-00942") > -1);
> }
> }
>
> This test method fails to catch the SQLException, passing
> it upwards and
> logging an error.
>
> The following test passes, however:
>
> public void testBadWrite2() {
> try {
>
> PersistenceManager.singleton().write("insert into noSuchTable
> values('hey')");
> fail("No exception writing to non-existent table");
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assertEquals("java.sql.SQLException", e.getClass().getName())
> assertTrue(e.toString().indexOf("ORA-00942") > -1);
> }
> }
>
> What am I missing?
> Thanks,
> Frank
